question: Question_C_04_(a)
statement:
Dead leaves accumulate on the ground in a forest at a rate of 5 grams
per square centimeter per year. At the same time, these leaves decompose
at a continuous rate of 50 percent per year.

(a) Write a differential equation for the total mass \emph{Q(t)} of dead
leaves (per square centimeter) at time \emph{t}.
sols:
We want to find the differential equation of the mass $Q$ of dead
leaves. This means we find the derivative of $Q$ with respect to time,
dependent on $Q$.

Therefore, we separate $\frac{d}{dt}Q$ into $\frac{d}{dt}Q_+$ the leaves
that are added every year and $\frac{d}{dt} Q_-$, that are removed every
year. Such that

$\frac{d}{dt} Q = \frac{d}{dt}Q_+ + \frac{d}{dt}Q_-$

The leaves (in grams) that are added every year per $cm^2$ are

$\frac{d}{dt}Q_+ = 5\frac{\text{grams}}{\text{year}\cdot cm^2}.$

The leaves that are removed every year depends on the amount of leaves:
According to the mass of leaves, half of the mass is lost every year:

$\frac{d}{dt} Q_- = -\frac{0.5Q}{\text{year}}.$

Since leave mass is lost, we put a negative sign here. Hence, our final
answer is

$\frac{d}{dt} Q =\frac{5\text{grams}}{\text{year}\cdot cm^2} - \frac{0.5Q}{\text{year}}.$

\emph{Note that this works out nicely so that the unit of Q is
grams/cm\textsuperscript{2}.} With units suppressed, the above is

$\frac{d}{dt} Q = 5 - 0.5Q.$
hints:
You want to find an equation for the derivative of $Q$ with respect to
time, $\frac{d}{dt} Q$, depending on $Q$.

The derivative $\frac{d}{dt}Q$ is a sum of two terms: The first term
represents the leaves which are added to the ground every year, the
second term presents the leaves which are removed from the ground every
year.

First, try to find these terms separately. Then add them and think about
the sign they should have. Which of the terms depends on \emph{Q}?
